catalogue_raissonne: Murase, Art through a Lifetime, no. 899
creditline: Mary Griggs Burke Collection, Gift of the Mary and Jackson Burke Foundation
description: tall vessel with graceful widening near top; fluted into six sections; short, thin neck with high mouth; two concentric inscribed circles below neck; horizontal inscribed markings around center
inscription:
Inscription

(possible illegible inscription inscribed onto underside of base near outer edge)
text: Vessels like this one, with its relatively narrow base that elegantly swells to broad shoulders and then narrows dramatically at the mouth, first gained popularity in China in the 900s, and came to be called “plum vessels,” or meiping in Chinese. Known as maebyeong in Korea, they are sometimes described as having been used for displaying branches of blossoming plum or other flowers but were more likely used to store plum wine. The lobes of this gracefully curving maebyeong are meant to suggest the sectioned exterior of a melon.
title: Lobed maebyeong
